{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3389459,"name":"Michael","username":"SourVenomz","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T17:40:29.137Z","cooked":"

This is my first year as a robot coder and I’m the only one. I need to code an arm that is a chain drive with 2 motors using CanSparkMax with Relative Encoders what would I do to code it. I don’t understand much when coming to this stuff

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T17:40:29.137Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466619,"topic_slug":"how-would-i-code-an-arm-for-a-cansparkmax-relative-encoder","display_username":"Michael","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66719,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"SourVenomz"},"post_url":"/t/how-would-i-code-an-arm-for-a-cansparkmax-relative-encoder/466619/1","custom_user_title":"SourVenomz","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3389480,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T18:02:53.716Z","cooked":"

How do you know about things like a SparkMAX on CAN and relative encoders? Do you have code from your team from previous seasons that you can refer to? While you may just be starting, it sounds like there are others on your team who are not just starting.

If you want to start from the basics, you can look at the Rev example code for position closed loop control. If you choose to go this direction, I suggest that you first start with just a motor and try to make the motor shaft control to a set number of rotations. If you can do that, you can take the much bigger step of connecting that motor to a gearbox and your arm chain drive and making the arm control to a desired angle. This really means that your motor shaft has turned enough to drive the arm to the desired angle through the gear reduction you have. If there is truly no one available that has ever done this before and no mentor who understands controls, I would strongly advise against writing code and testing it directly on the arm. Code problems with spinning wheels doesn’t usually result in a high level of danger. Code problems with an arm can get that mechanism behaving quite dangerously.

If you only have relative encoders, then you have the problem of zeroing the offset so you can move the arm to a known position and avoid attempting to move it beyond physical stops. There are three common ways teams deal with this:

  • Always start the arm in a reference position. This is simple, but has a serious potential failure mode.
  • Add limit switches. This is fairly simple to program and you can also wire it directly to the SparkMax, but you do need to think about what will happen if the wiring on the limit switch fails.
  • Add stall detection. This is a little fiddly to program, but in my experience ends up being the most reliable.

Even if you decide not to do stall detection, it’s still worth adding a current limit. With a CAN SparkMax, you can set a separate current limit for stall and free speed; you probably want to use a low (e.g. 10A) current limit at stall. It’s very easy to have a mechanism jam or push against a hard stop unnoticed until you smoke a motor.
